_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Description

Wisconsin Public Service, Weston  station, located in Rothschild, Wisconsin is planning to use 29% aqueous ammonia within the NOx emissions controls systems at Units 3 and 4.  Since the Facility has more than 20,000 pounds of aqueous ammonia at a concentration greater than 20%, it is required to submit a Risk Management Plan ("RMP") and comply with the requirements of 40 CFR 68. Weston  station is subject to Program 2 requirements for aqueous ammonia. 



Facility and Regulated Substances handled

The Weston  facility has three 45,000 gallon tanks of aqueous ammonia (29%) surrounded by a containment wall. The aqueous ammonia is used in the emissions control systems for units 3 and 4.  Note:  we administratively keep to max fill at 38,000 gallons.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Wisconsin Public Service is committed to the protection of its employees, the greater community and the environment. The facility recently established a system that identifies the hazards associated with the aqueous ammonia covered process and the control equipment required.  Senior management is committed to site safety and the implementation of safe procedures.

The facility also utilizes an Incident Reporting and Incident Investigation program to determine root cause(s) and appropriate corrective action(s) for incidents that occur.

The Facility has an emergency action plan in place. Wisconsin Public Service employees will not respond to accidental releases.  There is a comprehensive system in place that triggers the appropriate mechanisms to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response. Training for employees includes classroom instruction, hands on review of the equipment, and several incident simulation drills conducted each year.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program

Through completion of this RMP, Integrys has complied the elements as defined under 40 C FR Part 68 for program 2 facilities. Safety in

formation and operations/maintenance procedures are documented on-site. Periodic functions such as process hazard analysis and training are conducted on a regular basis. Audits of the overall RMP will be conducted on a regular basis to assure compliance with EPA regulations. Personnel training program includes an overview of the plant processes, safety and health hazards, emergency action plan and Risk Management Plan elements.  

The Facility has established a maintenance procedure to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors. 



Five Year Accident History

The Weston facility has not had an ammonia accident in the past five years at the facility.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Planned changes include 

1. Segregating the containment area to reduce offsite worst case analysis impacts, 

2. Installation of additional isolation valves to improve maintenance isolation capabilities 

3. Updated site emergency access procedures to reflect new responsibilities 

4. Changing of on site truck route to minimize potential accident risk

5. Identified new assembly and evacuation points in the event major event

6. Coordinated onsite meeting / tour with LEPC and local fire departments

7. Developed maintenance isolation procedures

8. Updated operations procedures

9. removal of ammonia related equipment not being utilized to improve human interface factors

10. Adding additional ammonia leak detection with alarms to aid in early leak detection
